div1.p: Dear John: - I think our last letters must have crossed, mine going west, yours east. I appreciate so much your interest in getting my M.SS. published. Now I have some 15 - 20 pages or extracts typed. I plan to send them out as soon as the holidays are over, & keep on until I give this method a thorough try.

Your gift to the University is surely fine. It is appropriate too, that the library then should have your collection as the nucleus of a Western Americana Collection. That is indeed a "natural" in view both of location & history. So much of the westward movement started from Missouri.

In view of what you said about Mrs. Miller & When the Tree Flowered, I reread that book. I don't see why they couldn't carve an excellent smaller book out of that, just as you suggested. On lending Russ Moran my copy of Poetic Values, I got such an enthusiastic response that I am in the process of rereading that & doing so slowly in order to savor every idea.

About ten days ago the weather after a long period of mildness took a sharp turn
45
for the worse. We had both cold & snow. I really can't complain for we were spared the deluge that settled on New York. But the cold was so sudden and sharp that I got out my Canadian overcoat, & wasn't for the first time in years.
Nita is well; she continues as usual to be busy with her classes. But she wouldn't have anyone feel sorry for her on that account. She loves to teach.

We are getting ready to visit our daughter's family in Urbana, Ill. We shall start (by train) Wed. & return Jan 2. I confess we rather dread the trip, but with two such small children, they can't come here.
And now dear friend of "many grasses, many snows", may your Christmas be merry, & most important, your health continue to be good.
div1.closer: Affectionately, Slade p.s. please give also my Christmas wishes to Alice, Hilda & Erica
